citation.unstructured_citation: In two studies on mobile phone purchase decisions, we investigated consumers’ decision strategies with a newly developed process tracing tool called InterActive Process Tracing (IAPT). This tool is a combination of several process tracing techniques (Active Information Search, Mouselab, and retrospective verbal protocol). After repeatedly choosing one of four mobile phones, participants formalized their strategy so that it could be used to make choices for them. The choices made by the identified strategies correctly predicted the observed choices in 73% (Experiment 1) and 67% (Experiment 2) of the cases. Moreover, in Experiment 2 we directly compared Mouselab and eye tracking with respect to their impact on information search and strategy description. We found only minor differences between these two methods. We conclude that IAPT is a useful research tool to identify choice strategies, and that using eye tracking technology did not increase its validity beyond that gained with Mouselab., Reisen, Nils and Hoffrage, Ulrich and Mast, Fred W, 1930-2975, 19302975, Judgment and decision making, decision making,decision strategies,eye tracking,mouselab,process tracing,verbal protocols, 8, 641–658, Identifying decision strategies in a consumer choice situation, 3, http://journal.sjdm.org/8801/jdm8801.html, 2008

A major task for all models of cognition is the development of representations and processes that both predict outcomes and are consistent with what we know about underlying cognitive structure. It is not surprising, therefore, that a single set of outputs can result from different ..., Willemsen, Martijn C. and Johnson, Eric J., A handbook of process tracing methods for decision research, Schulte-Mecklenbeck, M. and Kühberger, A. and Ranyard, R., 978-1848728646, Visiting the Decision Factory: Observing Cognition with MouselabWEB and other Information Acquisition Methods., 2011
Scharf, Sophie and Wiegelmann, Monika and Bröder, Arndt, Manuscript submitted for publication., Information Search in Everyday Decisions: The Generalizability of the Attraction Search Effect., 2018

Friends of DSN Eric Johnson and Martijn Willemsen have created an online version of the popular decision research tool MouseLab., Goldstein, Dan, jan, Want to get at what people are thinking?, http://www.decisionsciencenews.com/2006/01/29/want-to-get-at-what-people-are-thinking/, 2006, 1
